The application of these theoretical examples to the Baltimore area
is, of course, obvious if one regards the beltway as being the Beltway now
partially completed in the County, the single expressway to the north as
the Jones Falls Expressway, and the three additional radials as the
Southwest Expressway and the East-West Expressway.

These examples would seem to suggest that from the standpoint of
saving the central business district the real villain of the piece is the
Beltway. If this conclusion seems farfetched one has only to consider the
array of major shopping centers which are springing up at strategic points
along the Beltway or in close proximity to the Beltway. Included in this
list are Towson Plaza, Eastpoint, Harundale Mall, and Westview. Or
again, consider the new headquarters of the Department of Motor Vehicles
on Ritchie Highway. The State’s principal justification for picking this
site rather than one close to the center of Baltimore was its proximity to
the planned route of the Beltway.

The above schematic examples may also cast some additional light
on the question of substituting improved mass transit for expressways.
The health of the central business district is dependent upon superior
accessibility for all types of transportation. It has been indicated that it
requires four expressways extending outwards from the center at roughly
right angles, one to the other, to remedy the loss of vehicular accessibility

/resultmg from the construction of a beltway. Without this minimum
framework of expressways no amount of public transit improvement can
restore the central business district’s position of maximum accessibility
from all part of the metropolitan area. It may be the most accessible spot
from the standpoint of public transportation, but with the beltway and
without the radials it will no longer be the most accessible for automo-

bile travel.

The central business district’s position within the metropolitan area
is, of course, dependent upon many factors besides highways. Construc-
tion of the expressway pattern outlined in this report will not by itself
insure the future security of the central business district. It can safely
be said, however, that failure to continue with an expressway program
clearly focused on the downtown area will gravely jeopardize the many
efforts now being made to save the central business district. If we call a
halt after completion of the Jones Falls Expressway we face the prospect
of living in a city much more dispersed and scattered than our present
city. It will be more a large urban area than a city—one that will lack
much of the character and identity of Baltimore as we now know it.

Alternatives to Expressways

It is not hard to develop a case against urban expressways. We can
tell ourselves that the construction of expressways produces too great an
upheaval, that the hardships and other problems resulting from the relo-
cation of a good many thousands of people are excessive, that too much
property must be destroyed, and that the loss in tax base will be burden-
some. We can say that we should not be seduced by the availability of
large Federal grants and that we should be able to resist what might be
called the expressway hysteria allegedly affecting many other cities. We
can point to the fact that other metropolitan areas have already reached
the size which we expect to attain in the next twenty to thirty years and
that they did so without reliance on urban expressways. We can tell
ourselves that there are more things in life than the automobile and that
an ambitious expressway program would simply represent a final succumb-
ing of man to machine.
